clusters.title: Afghanistan earthquake kills more than 800, flattens villages
clusters.neutral_headline: Afghanistan Earthquake Kills Hundreds, Destroys Villages

items.title: Afghanistan earthquake kills more than 800, flattens villages
items.standfirst: A massive rescue operation was underway in Afghanistan on Monday, after a strong earthquake collapsed homes onto sleeping families in a remote, mountainous region, killing more than 800 people with the toll expected to rise, Taliban authorities said. FRANCE 24's Shahzaib Wahlah reports from Islamabad.
items.content: A massive rescue operation was underway in Afghanistan on Monday, after a strong earthquake collapsed homes onto sleeping families in a remote, mountainous region, killing more than 800 people with the toll expected to rise, Taliban authorities said. FRANCE 24's Shahzaib Wahlah reports from Islamabad.

items.title: ‘There is death in every home’, families say, after at least 800 killed in Afghanistan earthquake – as it happened
items.standfirst: Several villages in Kunar province ‘completely destroyed’, says public health ministry, as rescue operations take place. This live blog is closedMagnitude 6 earthquake hits eastern AfghanistanHow have you been affected by the earthquake?One resident in Afghanistan’s Nurgal district, one of the worst-affected areas in Kunar, said almost the entire village had collapsed under the force of the earthquake. “Children are under the rubble. The elderly are under the rubble. Young people are under the rubble,” the villager, who did not give his name, told the Associated Press.“We need help here,” he pleaded. “We need people to come here and join us. Let us pull out the people who are buried. There is no one who can come and remove dead bodies from under the rubble.” Continue reading...
items.content: Several villages in Kunar province ‘completely destroyed’, says public health ministry, as rescue operations take place. This live blog is closedMagnitude 6 earthquake hits eastern AfghanistanHow have you been affected by the earthquake?One resident in Afghanistan’s Nurgal district, one of the worst-affected areas in Kunar, said almost the entire village had collapsed under the force of the earthquake. “Children are under the rubble. The elderly are under the rubble. Young people are under the rubble,” the villager, who did not give his name, told the Associated Press.“We need help here,” he pleaded. “We need people to come here and join us. Let us pull out the people who are buried. There is no one who can come and remove dead bodies from under the rubble.” Continue reading...

items.title: Afghanistan earthquake: What we know - and what we don't
items.standfirst: Hundreds of people are thought to have died in the quake, which struck in a mountainous eastern region.
items.content: Hundreds of people are thought to have died in the quake, which struck in a mountainous eastern region.

items.title: More than 800 killed after strong quake hits Afghanistan
items.standfirst: There are fears the death toll will rise significantly as the area is remote and mountainous, making rescue operations difficult.
items.content: There are fears the death toll will rise significantly as the area is remote and mountainous, making rescue operations difficult.

items.title: More than 800 people killed by powerful quake in eastern Afghanistan
items.standfirst: An earthquake with a magnitude of 6 hit eastern Afghanistan, destroying multiple villages and killing more than 800 people, officials say.
items.content: An earthquake with a magnitude of 6 hit eastern Afghanistan, destroying multiple villages and killing more than 800 people, officials say.

items.title: Afghanistan: More than 800 dead and 2,700 injured in an earthquake
items.standfirst: Desperate Afghans clawed through rubble in search of missing loved ones after a strong earthquake killed some 800 people and injured more than 2,700 in eastern Afghanistan, according to figures provided Monday by the Taliban government. The 6.0 magnitude quake late Sunday hit towns in the province of Kunar, near the city of Jalalabad in neighboring Nangarhar province, causing extensive damage.
items.content: Desperate Afghans clawed through rubble in search of missing loved ones after a strong earthquake killed some 800 people and injured more than 2,700 in eastern Afghanistan, according to figures provided Monday by the Taliban government. The 6.0 magnitude quake late Sunday hit towns in the province of Kunar, near the city of Jalalabad in neighboring Nangarhar province, causing extensive damage.

items.title: At least 800 people killed as earthquake hits eastern Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Magnitude 6.1 tremor hits eastern provinces of Kunar and Nangarhar, and government spokesman warns toll could rise.
items.content: Magnitude 6.1 tremor hits eastern provinces of Kunar and Nangarhar, and government spokesman warns toll could rise.

items.title: Video: What we know about Afghanistan’s earthquake
items.standfirst: Entire villages have been destroyed by an earthquake in Afghanistan that has killed more than 800 people.
items.content: Entire villages have been destroyed by an earthquake in Afghanistan that has killed more than 800 people.

items.title: Massive Earthquake Rattles Afghanistan, Killing 800
items.standfirst: Rescue operations are underway in Afghanistan after a 6.0-magnitude earthquake killed at least 800 people and leveled residential buildings in the northeastern part of the country. Rescue crews are now digging through the rubble, searching for survivors.
items.content: Rescue operations are underway in Afghanistan after a 6.0-magnitude earthquake killed at least 800 people and leveled residential buildings in the northeastern part of the country. Rescue crews are now digging through the rubble, searching for survivors.

items.title: Over 800 killed, 2,500 injured in Afghanistan quake
items.standfirst: One of Afghanistan's worst earthquakes killed more than 800 people and injured at least 2,800, authorities said on Monday, as helicopters ferried the wounded to hospital after they were plucked from the rubble of homes being combed for survivors. FRANCE 24's Shazaib Wahlah has more.
items.content: One of Afghanistan's worst earthquakes killed more than 800 people and injured at least 2,800, authorities said on Monday, as helicopters ferried the wounded to hospital after they were plucked from the rubble of homes being combed for survivors. FRANCE 24's Shazaib Wahlah has more.

items.title: At least 800 dead after magnitude-6 earthquake hits eastern Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Rescuers try to reach people trapped under mud and debris while hampered by destroyed roads and steep terrainA powerful earthquake that hit mountainous eastern Afghanistan has left at least 800 people confirmed dead and injured about 2,500, Taliban officials have said as rescuers struggled to reach the worst-hit villages.The magnitude-6 earthquake struck several provinces close to the Pakistan border around midnight on Sunday, with the rugged region of Kunar the most severely affected. There were landslides and flooding. Continue reading...
items.content: Rescuers try to reach people trapped under mud and debris while hampered by destroyed roads and steep terrainA powerful earthquake that hit mountainous eastern Afghanistan has left at least 800 people confirmed dead and injured about 2,500, Taliban officials have said as rescuers struggled to reach the worst-hit villages.The magnitude-6 earthquake struck several provinces close to the Pakistan border around midnight on Sunday, with the rugged region of Kunar the most severely affected. There were landslides and flooding. Continue reading...

items.title: Afghanistan earthquake kills hundreds and destroys villages - all we know so far
items.standfirst: More than 800 people have been killed and at least 2,800 others injured after an earthquake hit eastern Afghanistan, according to Taliban state officials.
items.content: More than 800 people have been killed and at least 2,800 others injured after an earthquake hit eastern Afghanistan, according to Taliban state officials.

items.title: An earthquake devastates eastern Afghanistan, killing more than 800 people
items.standfirst: The 6.0 magnitude quake late Sunday hit a series of towns in the province of Kunar, near the city of Jalalabad in neighboring Nangahar province, causing extensive damage.
items.content: The 6.0 magnitude quake late Sunday hit a series of towns in the province of Kunar, near the city of Jalalabad in neighboring Nangahar province, causing extensive damage.(Image credit: Hedayat Shah)

items.title: At least 800 killed as powerful earthquake rocks Afghanistan
items.standfirst: At least 800 people have been killed and over 1,000 have been injured in Afghanistan after a 6.0-magnitude earthquake hit the country, Taliban officials said Monday.
items.content: At least 800 people have been killed and over 1,000 have been injured in Afghanistan after a 6.0-magnitude earthquake hit the country, Taliban officials said Monday.

ai_summary: A magnitude 6 earthquake struck eastern Afghanistan, causing widespread destruction.
Over 800 people are confirmed dead, with the death toll expected to rise significantly.
Remote, mountainous terrain hinders rescue operations in the affected areas.
Villages in Kunar province were reportedly completely destroyed by the earthquake.
International aid organizations are mobilizing to provide assistance to survivors.

clusters.title: Watch: BBC analyses the warmth and hand-holding at Xi, Modi and Putin's summit
clusters.neutral_headline: Xi, Putin, Modi Summit Focuses on Global Order

items.title: Watch: BBC analyses the warmth and hand-holding at Xi, Modi and Putin's summit
items.standfirst: The Chinese, Indian and Russian leaders were among those attending a regional security summit in China over the weekend.
items.content: The Chinese, Indian and Russian leaders were among those attending a regional security summit in China over the weekend.

items.title: Xi Jinping uses SCO summit to promote new world order
items.standfirst: At the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit, Chinese President Xi Jinping showcased strong ties with Russia’s Vladimir Putin and India’s Narendra Modi, using the platform to challenge US dominance and promote multilateral cooperation. Despite past tensions, Modi is increasingly aligning with China and Russia amid rising trade pressures from the U.S., while Xi prepares for a major military parade marking 80 years since World War II’s end.
items.content: At the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit, Chinese President Xi Jinping showcased strong ties with Russia’s Vladimir Putin and India’s Narendra Modi, using the platform to challenge US dominance and promote multilateral cooperation. Despite past tensions, Modi is increasingly aligning with China and Russia amid rising trade pressures from the U.S., while Xi prepares for a major military parade marking 80 years since World War II’s end.

items.title: SCO Summit: Cooperation or competition?
items.standfirst: The SCO summit in Tianjin highlights the growing strategic partnership between Russia and China, while India also seeks to assert its influence, particularly in the race for leadership in the Global South. Economic ties with Belarus are being strengthened, and Pakistan is among the key participants. While the summit signals a challenge to US dominance, there have been no formal security moves—just a message to Washington, which is watching closely. FRANCE 24 spoke with Natasha Kuhrt, Senior Lecturer in International Peace & Security, for her analysis.
items.content: The SCO summit in Tianjin highlights the growing strategic partnership between Russia and China, while India also seeks to assert its influence, particularly in the race for leadership in the Global South. Economic ties with Belarus are being strengthened, and Pakistan is among the key participants. While the summit signals a challenge to US dominance, there have been no formal security moves—just a message to Washington, which is watching closely. FRANCE 24 spoke with Natasha Kuhrt, Senior Lecturer in International Peace & Security, for her analysis.

items.title: Xi, Putin and Modi pledge unity at summit to counter US-led global order
items.standfirst: Xi Jinping was joined by Vladimir Putin and Narendra Modi at the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in China.
items.content: Xi Jinping was joined by Vladimir Putin and Narendra Modi at the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in China.

items.title: China, India, Russia seek to challenge US dominance at Tianjin summit
items.standfirst: A major summit in Tianjin kicked off Monday under the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation. Leaders including Xi Jinping, Vladimir Putin, and India’s Narendra Modi gathered to strengthen regional ties and push back against US influence on the global stage, as FRANCE 24's Delano D'Souza analyses.
items.content: A major summit in Tianjin kicked off Monday under the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation. Leaders including Xi Jinping, Vladimir Putin, and India’s Narendra Modi gathered to strengthen regional ties and push back against US influence on the global stage, as FRANCE 24's Delano D'Souza analyses.

items.title: Chinese President Xi hosts leaders from more than 20 countries at SCO summit
items.standfirst: President Xi is hosting the leaders from more than 20 countries for the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit in Tianjin, China, including Russian President Putin and Indian Prime Minister Modi. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports from Beijing on what to expect from the SCO summit.
items.content: President Xi is hosting the leaders from more than 20 countries for the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit in Tianjin, China, including Russian President Putin and Indian Prime Minister Modi. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports from Beijing on what to expect from the SCO summit.

items.title: China's Xi hosts Putin and Modi at Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit
items.standfirst: Chinese President Xi Jinping is hosting a high-profile summit with leaders from Russia, North Korea and India gathering among others in a challenge to U.S. influence.
items.content: Chinese President Xi Jinping is hosting a high-profile summit with leaders from Russia, North Korea and India gathering among others in a challenge to U.S. influence.

items.title: Xi Jinping criticises ‘bullying behaviour’ and Putin blames west for Ukraine war at Shanghai summit
items.standfirst: China’s leader urges attendees to oppose ‘cold war mentality’ while Russian president claims Ukraine war was ‘provoked by the west’Xi Jinping has criticised the “bullying behaviour” of other countries while Vladimir Putin has blamed the west for his war on Ukraine, on the second day of a major summit in China which seeks to challenge western-led multilateral blocs.The Shanghai Cooperation Summit (SCO) began in the city of Tianjin on Sunday, with Xi welcoming dozens of leaders from Eurasian member states and other partner and observer countries, including Putin, and Indian prime minister Narendra Modi. Continue reading...
items.content: China’s leader urges attendees to oppose ‘cold war mentality’ while Russian president claims Ukraine war was ‘provoked by the west’Xi Jinping has criticised the “bullying behaviour” of other countries while Vladimir Putin has blamed the west for his war on Ukraine, on the second day of a major summit in China which seeks to challenge western-led multilateral blocs.The Shanghai Cooperation Summit (SCO) began in the city of Tianjin on Sunday, with Xi welcoming dozens of leaders from Eurasian member states and other partner and observer countries, including Putin, and Indian prime minister Narendra Modi. Continue reading...

items.title: Putin, Modi and Erdoğan among leaders in China for talks with Xi
items.standfirst: Chinese president hosts bilateral meetings on sidelines of Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in TianjinXi Jinping and Vladimir Putin have met on the sidelines of a showpiece summit in China that seeks to challenge US-led, western-dominated blocs and is being attended by the leaders of more than two dozen nations.The Chinese and Russian leaders, who are closely allied under what they have termed a “limitless” partnership, discussed Putin’s recent meeting with Donald Trump, according to a Kremlin official, who gave no further details. Continue reading...
items.content: Chinese president hosts bilateral meetings on sidelines of Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in TianjinXi Jinping and Vladimir Putin have met on the sidelines of a showpiece summit in China that seeks to challenge US-led, western-dominated blocs and is being attended by the leaders of more than two dozen nations.The Chinese and Russian leaders, who are closely allied under what they have termed a “limitless” partnership, discussed Putin’s recent meeting with Donald Trump, according to a Kremlin official, who gave no further details. Continue reading...

items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi are among the 20 world leaders attending a regional security summit in China.

ai_summary: Leaders Xi Jinping, Vladimir Putin, and Narendra Modi met at the SCO summit in China.
The summit aimed to challenge US dominance and promote multilateral cooperation.
India is increasingly aligning with China and Russia amid trade pressures.
The summit signals a challenge to US influence, but no formal security moves occurred.
Modi highlighted India's energy ties with Russia despite US concerns.

items.title: EU chief von der Leyen’s aircraft GPS jammed over Bulgaria, Russian interference suspected
items.standfirst: The GPS system of European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's airplane was jammed Sunday shortly before landing in Bulgaria, an EU spokeswoman said Monday. Bulgarian authorities suspect the disruption was due to Russian interference, but it was not clear if the chartered flight was deliberately targeted, she added.
items.content: The GPS system of European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's airplane was jammed Sunday shortly before landing in Bulgaria, an EU spokeswoman said Monday. Bulgarian authorities suspect the disruption was due to Russian interference, but it was not clear if the chartered flight was deliberately targeted, she added.

items.title: Russia suspected of GPS interference after EU Commission president's plane 'forced to land using paper maps'
items.standfirst: A plane carrying European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen suffered GPS jamming as a result of suspected Russian interference, an EU spokesperson has confirmed to Sky News.
items.content: A plane carrying European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen suffered GPS jamming as a result of suspected Russian interference, an EU spokesperson has confirmed to Sky News.

ai_summary: The plane carrying EU Commission President von der Leyen was affected by GPS jamming.
Bulgarian authorities suspect Russian interference in the GPS disruption.
The plane was forced to land in Bulgaria using paper maps.
An EU spokeswoman confirmed the GPS jamming incident.
Such instances of GPS interference are expected to escalate.

clusters.title: Democratic, Republican strategists on Trump administration's latest immigration, crime moves

items.title: Democratic, Republican strategists on Trump administration's latest immigration, crime moves
items.standfirst: Republican strategist Jeanette Hoffman and Democratic strategist Hyma Moore weigh in on a judge blocking the potential deportation of several unaccompanied children to Guatemala, and the Trump administration's plans to expand immigration enforcement in Chicago.
items.content: Republican strategist Jeanette Hoffman and Democratic strategist Hyma Moore weigh in on a judge blocking the potential deportation of several unaccompanied children to Guatemala, and the Trump administration's plans to expand immigration enforcement in Chicago.

items.title: Guatemala says it is willing to receive hundreds of deported children from US
items.standfirst: Announcement comes a day after a US federal judge halted the deportation of 10 unaccompanied Guatemalan minorsGuatemala is ready and willing to receive about 150 unaccompanied children of all ages each week from the United States, the country’s president has said, a day after a US federal judge halted the deportation of 10 Guatemalan children.Those children had already boarded a plane when a court responded to an emergency appeal on Sunday. They were later returned to the custody of the Office of Refugee Resettlement. Continue reading...
items.content: Announcement comes a day after a US federal judge halted the deportation of 10 unaccompanied Guatemalan minorsGuatemala is ready and willing to receive about 150 unaccompanied children of all ages each week from the United States, the country’s president has said, a day after a US federal judge halted the deportation of 10 Guatemalan children.Those children had already boarded a plane when a court responded to an emergency appeal on Sunday. They were later returned to the custody of the Office of Refugee Resettlement. Continue reading...

items.title: Judge blocks Trump administration effort to deport Guatemalan migrant children
items.standfirst: A federal judge blocked the Trump administration from sending unaccompanied children to Guatemala unless they have a deportation order. CBS News' Camilo Montoya-Galvez reports.
items.content: A federal judge blocked the Trump administration from sending unaccompanied children to Guatemala unless they have a deportation order. CBS News' Camilo Montoya-Galvez reports.

items.title: Judge blocks Trump administration move to deport Guatemalan children

items.content: Advocacy groups sought emergency action amid reports planes carrying the children were about to take off.

items.title: Judge blocks deportation of Guatemalan migrant children at last minute
items.standfirst: The case involves 10 migrants between 10- and 17-years-old who entered the U.S. without authorization and without their parents or legal guardians.
items.content: The case involves 10 migrants between 10- and 17-years-old who entered the U.S. without authorization and without their parents or legal guardians.

items.title: Guatemala says it suggested that U.S. send its unaccompanied migrant children home
items.standfirst: As a U.S. federal judge blocked the deportation of unaccompanied Guatemalan children, the government of Guatemala says in a statement it suggested the U.S. return its children to their home country.
items.content: As a U.S. federal judge blocked the deportation of unaccompanied Guatemalan children, the government of Guatemala says in a statement it suggested the U.S. return its children to their home country.(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

items.title: Hundreds of unaccompanied Guatemalan children can stay in the U.S. for now, judge says
items.standfirst: A federal district judge issued a temporary restraining order after the U.S. attempted to deport hundreds of unaccompanied Guatemalan children without proper immigration proceedings.
items.content: A federal district judge issued a temporary restraining order after the U.S. attempted to deport hundreds of unaccompanied Guatemalan children without proper immigration proceedings. (Image credit: Johan Ordonez)

ai_summary: A judge blocked the Trump administration's deportation of Guatemalan children.
The case involves unaccompanied minors who entered the US without authorization.
Guatemala stated its willingness to receive deported children from the US.
The judge's decision came at the last minute, halting the deportations.
The Guatemalan government suggested the US return its unaccompanied children.

clusters.title: Israel committing genocide in Gaza, world's leading experts say
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Committing Genocide in Gaza, Scholars Say

items.title: Israel committing genocide in Gaza, world's leading experts say
items.standfirst: The world's leading association of genocide scholars cited several actions by Israel, including attacks on the healthcare sector and the killing of children.
items.content: The world's leading association of genocide scholars cited several actions by Israel, including attacks on the healthcare sector and the killing of children.

items.title: Israel committing genocide in Gaza, scholars group says
items.standfirst: Leading genocide scholars formally declare that Israel’s war on Gaza meets the UN’s definition of genocide.
items.content: Leading genocide scholars formally declare that Israel’s war on Gaza meets the UN’s definition of genocide.

items.title: Israel committing genocide in Gaza, world’s top scholars on the crime say
items.standfirst: International Association of Genocide Scholars resolution backed by 86% of members who votedAn overwhelming majority of members of the world’s leading genocide scholars’ association have backed a resolution stating that Israel’s actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of the crime.Eighty-six per cent of those who voted in the 500-member International Association of Genocide Scholars (IAGS) supported the motion. The resolution states that “Israel’s policies and actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of genocide in article II of the United Nations convention for the prevention and punishment of the crime of genocide (1948).” Continue reading...
items.content: International Association of Genocide Scholars resolution backed by 86% of members who votedAn overwhelming majority of members of the world’s leading genocide scholars’ association have backed a resolution stating that Israel’s actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of the crime.Eighty-six per cent of those who voted in the 500-member International Association of Genocide Scholars (IAGS) supported the motion. The resolution states that “Israel’s policies and actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of genocide in article II of the United Nations convention for the prevention and punishment of the crime of genocide (1948).” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The International Association of Genocide Scholars declared Israel's actions genocide.
The scholars cited attacks on healthcare and the killing of children.
An overwhelming majority of members supported the resolution.
The resolution stated Israel's actions meet the legal definition of genocide.
The group's resolution was backed by 86% of voting members.

items.title: Levi’s says anti-Americanism linked to Trump policies could dent UK sales
items.standfirst: Firm warns changing sentiment towards US brands could prompt shoppers to choose European productsLevi’s has said that “rising anti-Americanism as a consequence of the Trump tariffs and governmental policies” could drive British shoppers away from its denim.The company, which distributes Levi’s and Dockers clothing brands, issued the warning in its UK accounts, where it reported sales had risen 8.8% to £96.8m and pre-tax profits were up 23% to £9.6m. It said the Levi’s brand had “retained its attractiveness despite a tense consumer climate and declining customer frequency in the retail sector”. Continue reading...

It said the Levi’s brand had “retained its attractiveness despite a tense consumer climate and declining customer frequency in the retail sector”. Continue reading...

items.title: Gaza aid flotilla departs Barcelona again after being forced back by storm
items.standfirst: A Gaza-bound flotilla set sail for a second time after fierce Mediterranean winds on Monday forced the mission carrying humanitarian aid and hundreds of pro-Palestinian activists, including Greta Thunberg, to return to Barcelona. The Global Sumud Flotilla, made up of around 20 boats, is expected to arrive in Gaza in mid-September.
